turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How long was that --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: -- in this whole record --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How long was that supposed confession?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: About five minutes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Record 69, it's about 12 lines down, question is, State whether or not you told him, the defendant, there might be 30 or 40 people there in the next few minutes?
Answer I said it was possible.
Now, to me that is the only piece of evidence --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What -- now what -- where is the -- the piece of evidence where the defendant said he was told there might be 30 or 40 people there?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's on record page 69.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I mean, the petitioner, they have -- they have said -- stating there'd be 30 or 40 people there.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, now this --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What did he say was the reason?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: What did the petitioner say, he said that there was -- that the Chief of Police told him that there were 30 or 40 people that wanted to get in there to get him, I believe is the way he put it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was the Chief of Police -- did he make any further statements in this -- about it at all?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: To my knowledge this is at -- on page 69.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is -- could you quickly turn to the testimony of the petitioner on this very point, what is his comment of these 30 or 40 people?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I believe 128.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: At the bottom of the page.
Question What caused you to be afraid, Frank?
Answer Well, it was the conversation that Chief Norman Young was talking, when he said, 30 or 40 peoples outside.
Then from the conversation of this officer down at Dumas and the way he was talking, in other words.
He says peoples, it were somebody outside and were someone that was outside wanting to get in to me.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This officer down at Dumas, that's a different --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That happened a different night, the record is clear on that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Isn't that -- and that you say were --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: This, but this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that -- is there a -- is that also unquestioned, is there also agreement on that?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: But only as to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As to what --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: - what is in the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) of the confession, is that it?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: What happened at Dumas is fairly, clearly happened a night later.
There is -- there is just, I mean the evidence in the record is just abundant on that.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: After the confession?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: What occurred at Dumas --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Was after the confession?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Was after the confession.
I don't think there is any question about that and I have the record cited to show what happened after the confession at 58, 60, 66, 90, 91 and 106.
Now, at record 91, now this is petitioner testifying, he forgot himself here and he -- what was this statement the man said you about hanging somebody?

Answer And the petitioner has testified and he has mental lapse here, he wasn't on guard, while he was questioning me, as I said before, he was questioning me, had I confessed that I did it, and I told him, yes, I had.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, at -- on page -- at the top of page 128 --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I believe he said, with reference to the same conversation that the Chief testified about -- Chief of Police, Chief Norman Young said 30 or 40 people were outside wanting to get in to me.
And he asked me if I wanted to make a confession he would try to keep them out.
Did any -- did the state ask the Chief whether or not that was true?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Page 69.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Page 69.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I believe it was the -- Mr. Branton was cross-examining the Chief on that point.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But where did he deny that.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: At -- that state whether or not -- it's about the -- about 12 lines down on page 69.
State whether or not you told him, the defendant, there might be 30 or 40 people there in the next few minutes.
And Chief Young answered, I said it was possible.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that pretty plainly refers to the statement that this man made that he said there were 30 or 40 people out there waiting to get him, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well now, it goes on here is the reason that I have a question about --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did -- did the state ever ask that the policeman ever deny it, Chief of Police ever deny it that other parts of the statement that he made about the 30 or 40 people?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: To my knowledge he didn't, this is it.
He just says, I said it was possible.
And I think another place in the record somewhere, he was testifying about it and he says, I said it was possible there could be that many.
And he said, It was possible there would have been that many.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you say that's the --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's the Chief of Police.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) as I understood you, you say that is according to your view and I should just apply the question, that the only thing that is -- as to which there is agreement between the petitioner --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, that's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that the State couldn't, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's -- that's the only thing I think that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, that result --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: -- that you might infer any -- any course from --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There will be (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That would be the only statement in the whole record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, and there's no controversy that the Chief of Police said something about 30 or 40 people in the next few minutes, is that right?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: But then he goes on right on page 69 --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Nobody -- nobody every denied the statement of petitioner that the Chief of Police told him that they were out there to get him.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: What I -- I wish you would note Mr. Justice Black, how this question is phrased on page 69.
You'll notice that he doesn't mention anything that 30 or 40 people to go in there to get you, he said there'd be 30 or 40 people there in a few minutes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand that.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Now, there were several people --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you'd have a --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: -- that did come in after this confession who witnessed it.
Now, I don't personally know and can't gain from the record whether the -- the Chief was referring to the witnesses or he actually did say something about a mob.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you -- the fact remains, does it not, that you have a statement by the petitioner that he said -- he said there were 30 or 40 people, that he said they were there to get him, you have no denial of that in the record by anybody representing Arkansas.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I believe that's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, that isn't quite regarding the testimony because the action to include not only the connotation that Chief Norman Young but also of that officer at Dumas, can they --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, I believe you're on a different page.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm talking about page 128.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, I was talking about page 69.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understand that, that when a (Inaudible)

I understand that the chief of your argument is the Chief of Police simply says, 30 people there in the next few minutes without saying what the people were there for, what their purpose was, that is correct, isn't it?
That's your point.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's -- that's true.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, what I'm -- I'm turning to what the petitioner has made on page 28 -- 128.
And the petitioner gets in the phrase to get -- to get into me, he concludes that act referring not only what Chief Norman Young said there, but also what the officer down at Dumas said.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's at the bottom of the page.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But what about the top of the page?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: -- at the bottom of page 128.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about the top of the page, is that --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Only the part says, wanting to get in to.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, has that been disputed by you here?
He would try to keep them out, has that been -- has that been disputed by you?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: In your brief on page 11 counsel of your brief a few lines from the bottom of the page.
You state it as apparently what Chief Young meant was there would be other people there to witness the confession.
Now, where is that?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That is what I get out from page 69 because when you come on down and read in context without taking it out of context.
If you take it out of context, it looks -- you don't know.
But, if you go on down close to the bottom of -- that's the --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But the thing that's wrong with that is that when somebody did knock on the door to want to come in, he wouldn't let anybody in, even though he was the Sheriff to witness the confession.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's true, he -- he had -- he -- in his testimony, the Sheriff said, I had promised Frank, the petitioner, that he could make this confession to me in private and he kept his promise and he wouldn't let anyone else in, he testified until he got Frank's permission.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: So that -- that all adds up against what you say in the bottom of page 11 as to the reason that he -- he would.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I don't think so if you read it in context.
On 69, right after he says, I said it was possible.
Did you go downstairs to your office?
Yes.
Was his confession interrupted?
Says, It was by a knock on the door, and he went to the door, he said the then Sheriff and a State Trooper were at the door.
Did you permit them to come in?
"I did not.
Did you tell them anything about the defendant?
He said, I told them that he was making an oral confession.
And said then, Did he complete his confession roughly, then what you do?
I asked him if he would mind the Sheriff and Sergeant Halsell to come in.
How much later was that?
He says, Not more than five minutes.
Question Then, did the other people come in?
Connect it back up here, there would be 30 or 40 there, reading it directly in context.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So what you have here, I wish you'd state whether or not you think that shows the confession was coerced or not.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I do not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, let me ask a question.
You have undisputed testimony to this effect, no witnesses deny it.
Chief Norman Young said 30 or 40 people were outside waiting to get in to me, and he asked me if I wanted to make a confession, he would try to keep them out.
And nobody has denied that.
In your judgment, if that is true, was this a free and voluntary confession?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I think it was.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Even with that statement?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: For -- for this reason.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Even with that statement made?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I don't think possibly the statement as you put it was not denied as such, but during Chief Young's testimony, he explained it in a different way, I mean answered the questions in a different way where you could possibly draw any inference you want to, you --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He made no statement on (Inaudible) about whether this man -- whether 30 or 40 people there, the statement was true, that he had told this young fellow that there were 30 to 40 people out there waiting to get him.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: But the reason that I think that it wasn't coerced is his subsequent demeanor after that.

That is shown by the testimony of the court reporter and the other witnesses to the effect that, well, a few minutes later, here he is testifying, and he was watching the court reporter to takes the notes in shorthand, and he is very careful not to talk too fast, so she'll get everything down that he is saying.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: And he shows no outward signs of fear, and that would lead me to believe that there is just no substance to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you do have --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: -- the argument of a coerced confession.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you do have to defend it, do you not, on the basis that this undisputed testimony in the record.
The Chief of Police told him five minutes before the confession, you got to go ahead and talk to the 30 or 40 out there waiting to get you.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, it depends on whose testimony you're going to believe, the Chief of Police --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, who denies it?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: They didn't deny it as such.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Thomas before you sit down, what have you got to say about the proof, the lack of proof?
Now as I understood Mr. Branton, as I understand the briefs, this man was arrested at about 10 o'clock Wednesday morning.

He was given no food on Wednesday, he was given the sandwich, I think, your witnesses say two sandwiches on -- at noon on Thursday, and then nothing more to eat until after he -- after he confessed on Friday afternoon.
Now, what do you have to say about that?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: There is no testimony in the record on behalf of the State that shows whether he was fed or not.
The -- Chief Young testified that the first meal in the morning at the jail was at 8, the evening meal started around between 4 and 5.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And they took him by 6 o'clock to Little Rock.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Yes, sir, but --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So he had no breakfast.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: The -- the record positively shows that he was fed two sandwiches or at least one, by his own testimony, at noon that day.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That after he came --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: 26 hours (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: After they had finished taken the lie detector --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: 26 hours after he was arrested.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, he was arrested on --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: At 10 o'clock on Wednesday morning (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: 11 o'clock on Wednesday --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- or about noon on -- on Thursday as I understood it.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: He was arrested on Wednesday, the sandwiches were on Thursday noon --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thursday (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: -- when -- that was after he had completed the lie detector test, and was turned back over to the police officer.
They fed him and returned him to Pine Bluff, where he was placed in jail for the remainder of the night, which would indicate to me that he was there at the time that the food was served.
Certainly he was there the next morning, because he wasn't taken out of that cell until he wanted to confess at approximately 1 o'clock on Friday.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But he testified -- he testified that he did not receive any food and although the State took notice of that, all they would say was that he was in the building when the others were fed.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I don't know whether they could prove it Your honor or not.
As I say I wasn't in that phase of the case, I have only been connected with it during the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But that's all that -- that that's (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: But there is nothing -- I will say that very frankly there's nothing in the record any direct testimony that would reflect anything to the contrary other than what the petitioner said.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

Well now do you not -- do you not think that a 19-year-old man, whatever you want to call him or a boy, whichever it is, who was thrown into jail and held for 26 hours, without any food, and then is given one or two sandwiches.
And then this questions off and on for another 26 hours or so before he's given any more food.
And half of the time without even any shoes on, dragged around the country.
Do you not think that that has some effect upon his -- his mental condition and his willingness to -- to do what the police wanted to do?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, Your Honor may I say you this.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I -- reading the record, and staying strictly with the record, I have not drawn the same conclusions from this that you have, like you say --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But what good --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: -- where he is dragged around the contrary without any shoes, he was merely taken from Pine Bluff to Little Rock without shoes where he was given shoes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but as I read the record, your own witnesses said that his shoes were taken from him about 6:30 in the morning and then they took him to Little Rock and they gave him some shoes about 4:30 in the afternoon.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, the officer testified that -- Officer Halsell testified that he gave him the shoes immediately upon his arrival at State Police Headquarters that morning.
Now, it was the petitioner who said that he didn't receive the shoes until 4:30 in the afternoon.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I made a mistake about (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: But I say according to the record --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: -- if the facts were as you stated to me, then my answer would have been different.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, let's just -- let's leave the shoes out of it, and just take that food conversation.
Do you not -- do you think that that to his conduct compatible with free and voluntary confession?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I don't think that one factor alone would affect it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No.
Well, how about -- how about (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's because I'm very (Inaudible) myself voluntarily.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How about that factor coupled with the other one, to the effect that the Sheriff told him that there were 30 or 40 people out there and he tried to protect him.
Would that be --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well now, on the -- on the morning -- on that Friday morning, I -- I don't believe there was any dispute in a record that he was placed back in the jail on his return from Little Rock, for the remainder of the night.
They had to put him there the next morning.
I mean, he had to be in jail the next morning during the time they served breakfast.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well that doesn't prove that they gave him any breakfast.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And there's -- there is no one for the State who testified that they did give him any breakfast.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There's no one who testified that any if at all except those two sandwiches 26 hours after he was arrested.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: But by his own testimony he said the reason I confessed is because I was afraid of what the Sheriff told me and what the jailer at Dumas told me.
He never once says in his testimony that the reason he confessed was because he was hungry.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, he testified the fact that he didn't get any food, didn't he?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, he said he had two sandwiches and the coke and a candy bar and some peanuts and testified that Sergeant Halsell, although he had had breakfast, now this was in Dumas that morning in jail, Sergeant Halsell, he told him he was still hungry and he stopped outside of Dumas and bought him ham and eggs and milk.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Ham and eggs?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: When was that, after his defense?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well that was -- apparently after -- that was after he had confessed, that was at Dumas.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Well, that makes a difference, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: But he also fed him, the day that he had him in Little Rock, of course there is no -- it is like you say there is no testimony to the contrary, to contradict that he said he wasn't fed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well then, that's the reason why I -- I asked you whether there isn't more than just the one point, you say the only issue in the case, as you see it is what the Sherriff is supposed to have told him just beforehand.

But you don't attach any significance to the fact that this young was kept in jail and questioned and night and day at various times, I don't say continuously, and that he was given no food, except one or two sandwiches over a period of more than two day.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, the record will reflect that he was given more then just the two sandwiches.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well when -- where -- where --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: By his own testimony, he says in there that besides that that he was given a candy bar, that he was given some peanuts and on his own testimony he said that the jailer threatened him in Dumas before he confessed and that he goes in all that that he was fed before he was confessed.
Of course, that isn't true because --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And you tell us that those things happened afterwards so the --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's true --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- the statement about -- about the --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: But he still received -- he --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) about getting the time he got that candy and so forth in Dumas.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: No.
He didn't say he got it in Dumas, he said he got it in the jail.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) ham and eggs for breakfast on Friday morning.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Sergent Halsell purchased that for him outside of Dumas.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, what was the defense on the merits?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could I ask --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: I -- I don't quite follow you Judge Whittaker.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, did -- he denied guilt on the finding of the case, the defense on the merits that --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: No, no.
He -- he admitted that he killed the man.
But he said he --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: What was the defense?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: He said he did it in a sudden heat of passion.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That doesn't appear in this record, I (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: No, Your -- no --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- typewritten record this morning and I looked at it hastily, am I --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: There is much at this recording --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Am I correct in thinking that he took the stand in his own defense apart from the confession, he admitted that he killed the man and that the defense was that he had done it in self defense, is that correct?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Self defense and sudden heat of passion, there were two --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Heat of passion.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: (Inaudible) there.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But he never repudiated his confession on the witness stand which he did -- where he testified in his own behalf, did he?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: He said the -- I believe that that wasn't the truth, and that he was telling the truth when he testified in his behalf, that he did repudiate the confession.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, I don't understand that statement.
Where does the confession deviate from his testimony in his affirmative defense?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: It may -- it may not -- you mean, how does his testimony differ from his plea of --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: It -- of his confession?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: It doesn't itself in that sense.
As I remember the record, he said that the confession he made was not true and the prosecuting attorney said, What is the truth?
And on objection by Mr. Branton the Court stopped the prosecutor from pursuing that line of questioning any further.
And I believe that testimony was taken in chambers possibly at around 91.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, was there testimony before (Inaudible) on the affirmative defense that petitioner slew his employer?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Yes, but it is not in this record.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: It's not in this record.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: It's in the typewritten record that you haven't --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But you haven't printed that part of the testimony in that --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's -- that's true.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- typewritten record to get the whole picture of what this fellow testified to.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's -- that's correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You've got to look at the typewritten record --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- is that it?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is the -- is the $400 of the employer's money that was found in petitioner's home, is that -- this evidence -- is that in this record?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Yes, it is in this one and the other one too and the typewritten, it's in both of them.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did he admit or deny he got the money?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Well, he took the officer's -- very frankly admitted that he took it, he took them to where he had it hidden in a piano.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You're talking about the confession.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: And also there's some other testimony and I don't know whether it's in this particular record or in the typewritten.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, this typewritten testimony, this typewritten record, he admitted that he took the money, didn't he?

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Testified affirmative of having taken the money.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: He even took them, the officers to the spot that he thrown the iron rod where he crushed his employer's skull and point out this is where I threw it and that's where a man had found it.
There was an ample independent evidence which he can -- been convicted of --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There's ample (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: -- other than the confession.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The ample independent evidence was that he denied that he had made the confession that they offered against him.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: No, he did never deny making the confession.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I mean as they stated it.

turn.speaker: thorp_thomas
turn.label: Mr. Thorp Thomas
turn.text: He said that that wasn't the truth, but I don't think he -- in any, in the other record the typewritten record, he tells his story that is different than the confession.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Branton, you may -- you may finish if you wish (Inaudible) want to come back tomorrow.

turn.speaker: wiley_a_branton
turn.label: Mr. Wiley A. Branton
turn.text: May it please the Court.
I noticed that there has been considerable questioning back and forth as to what the Chief of Police meant about whether or not there were 30 or 40 people downstairs just prior to the confession.

I wish to point out to the Court that on bottom of page 113 on cross-examination of the Chief of Police by myself, I specifically asked him this question, State whether or not anything was said to the defendant to the effect that there would be 30 or 40 people there in a few minutes that wanted to get him?
His answer was, I told him that would be possible, that would be that many.
It was possible there could be that many.
I think that clears up what the Chief of Police meant because certainly the question was, Did you tell him that there'd be that many people there to get him.
Now the State contends what he meant was, there'd be 30 or 40 people there to witness the confession.
And certainly to use the language to get him, it can't mean but one thing namely just what it implied that there would be possible mob violence.
The defendant specifically repudiates his confession on page 94.
It does not appear in the transcript of record printed here as to the defense on the merits for the simple reason that the only part of the record here is that part designated by the petitioner.

Naturally, the petitioner was only going to designate that part that this Court would consider on certiorari, we didn't feel that we should make our state's case, they failed to cross designate, it's not here.

The defendant took the witness stand on his own behalf admitted to the slaying, but states that he was working there, that he and his employer got into a very heated argument that the employer slapped him and that he reached down, passed an iron bar, and that he jumped over this counter, that they fought over, he got it away from him and beat him with an iron bar and when he realized what he had done that his first thought was to get away and the man was there checking up and he took some money.

Now it should be remembered that this defendant was not charged with a crime of murder in the first degree while in the perpetration of a felony, because the State would have had -- would have had an easier case in the Arkansas law, no premeditation being required.
Now, they're trying to imply here that he was charged with robbing the man.
But he wasn't even charged with that.
It's true that he had 400 some odd dollars but he was never charged with a slaying while the perpetration of a felony.
And that is significant.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Did that testimony (Inaudible) $400 from the deceased?
(Inaudible)

turn.speaker: wiley_a_branton
turn.label: Mr. Wiley A. Branton
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) and the testimony went in.

turn.speaker: wiley_a_branton
turn.label: Mr. Wiley A. Branton
turn.text: If Your Honor please, we object to the information in the first place because --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, did you object to the inference that the $400 of the deceased money was found in the home of the deceased --

turn.speaker: wiley_a_branton
turn.label: Mr. Wiley A. Branton
turn.text: We objected --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- of the petitioner.

turn.speaker: wiley_a_branton
turn.label: Mr. Wiley A. Branton
turn.text: We objected to the testimony of Sergent Halsell who first testified, yes, sir we did.
But if -- if you have reference to the objection of the possible commission of other crimes insofar as that angle is concerned we did not raise that as a legal question.
As to that payroll record, the payroll record is -- the payroll record accurately reflects the actual number of persons who served on the jury in Jefferson County.
And therefore in answer to a question as to the number of Negroes who served the preceding year, one commissioner said that he couldn't use all of those who had been used a year before.
The record shows that only two or perhaps four had been used a year before.
Anybody who had been excused would not be on the payroll record and therefore could be used on the next panel.
The testimony as to that payroll record is uncontradicted.
The State says if we don't know how to add and that the total number there is 640, we still get 669.

We attempted to put the sheriff on the stand, the record, the permanent record is kept not in the Sheriff's office, but in the office of the circuit clerk the same person who said he had no such record.

And the Court didn't even want us to burden the trial because after all we had been in court for half a day and if you take longer than two days in Arkansas to electrocute a Negro, why then, you have an unusually long trial.
So we wound up in two days.
And the Court didn't want this trial delayed and suggested that I get on the stand and testify.

Now we submit that after having been invited to make this testimony and certainly we have the burden, then the burden of rebutting that presumption which we had raised was on the State and they offered no testimony whatsoever to rebut the evidence which we had offered.
As to whether or not there were more Negroes excused from jury service as compared with white, the record is silent.
As I say, we'd have go outside the record but certainly the percentage of Negroes who served would be even more disparaging if we used the accurate record rather than the payroll record.
And even if that was not true there is nothing here that the State says that people get excused for two things, having made this, and this, that and the other.

And I don't think that this Court can take any judicial knowledge of the fact or be presumptuous enough to say that Negroes have any more (Inaudible) than white people, that therefore a greater percentage of Negroes would asked to be excused than would white.

And as to the inference that might be raised by such a situation as you have in Jefferson County with such a small number of people, being -- Negroes being called for jury service over a long period of time.

This Court said, in another decision coming out of Texas that it should tax the credulity of the Court, to say that mere chance resulted in such few Negroes being called for jury service in a county, where you have such a high percentage of Negroes making up the population and a high percentage of qualified voters.
Another question was directed to the Attorney General as to whether or not in Jefferson County you would find an unusually high percentage of illiterate colored people in that county.
Now I've lived in that county all in my life.
Insofar as Negroes are concerned, Jefferson County is the leading cultural and educational county of the State of Arkansas for Negroes.
It is the home of the Arkansas State College for Negroes.
It is the home of (Inaudible) Institute for Negroes.
For many, many years the Negro High School has been accredited by the North Central Association.

And I dare say that percentage wise there is a greater percentage of literate Negroes in Jefferson County than any other county in the State of Arkansas, and that the literacy qualifications of Negroes is probably equal to or superior percentage wise than the literacy test of white people in that county because there is not a single white college within that county.

And certainly anytime that you have a county where you've had a college down through the years, there generally is a higher literacy portion in that particular county than you have in a county where you do not have a college.
